snippet: Letting law students take the bar exam after two years would keep many from drowning in debt — and force law schools to make their third-year curriculums worthwhile.
abstract: Op-Ed article by legal scholars Daniel B Rodriguez and Samuel Estreicher expresses support for proposal being considered in New York that would allow law students to take state bar exam after two years of school instead of three now required; asserts that move would keep many students from drowning in debt, and force law schools to make their third-year curriculums worthwhile.

byline.original: By DANIEL B. RODRIGUEZ and SAMUEL ESTREICHER

lead_paragraph: Letting law students take the bar exam after two years would keep many from drowning in debt — and force law schools to make their third-year curriculums worthwhile.

headline.seo: Practicing Law Should Not Mean Living in Bankruptcy
headline.main: Make Law Schools Earn a Third Year
headline.print_headline: Make Law Schools Earn a Third Year
